title: What would cause a brand new computer laptop to run slowly right from the get-go? - Quora

response.answer_text: The real answer is: All of the earlier answers, and more. Software (bloatware) - loads of laptops have software included to ‘help’ the consumer. As a techie, the very first thing I do with laptops is reinstalling windows. They almost always include some anti-virus that just eats all the resources all the time. But other software might be using your resources as well. Like custom software to play DVD’s on the included DVD player for some reason might use your CPU all the time.HDD - Having a traditional harddrive is a lot slower then a SSD. upgrading from an HDD to an SSD will improve your laptop speeds always. There are faster and slower SSD’s however. And they are more expansive. Also, not all laptops are upgradeable.Outdated - I know a lot of people who buy “brand new” laptops, with specs of 3 - 4 years ago. Well this should speak for itself.Thermals - A computer (it’s components) use energy, and everything that uses energy will heat up. To not let everything smelt and burn computers turn down their energy if they become to hot. This means, they will throttle your CPU power if it becomes to hot. In a traditional desktop, it’s less of a problem, there is loads of room to dissipate the heat. A laptop is quite confined. This is a problem from model to model and might even be a non-issue.Laptops are inherently lower powered - A laptop can’t power the same electronics as a desktop can. They are battery powered so they have a limit on how much energy they can give you at any given moment. Desktops do have a limit as well, but it’s way higher. With the new Nvidia 10-series, the GPU department made some huge improvements however. The CPU’s, even though they have the same number, are slower then their desktop counter parts. In high-end laptops the i7–7700HQ is used. This CPU is significantly slower then a i7–7700k seen in most high-end desktops. (this point ties in with thermals)Horrible bad and misleading marketing - I can’t tell you how many times I wanted to hit some salesperson when (s)he was trying to sell me a laptop as being able to do certain stuff. Anything using an Intel Celeron or Atom processor won’t do anything more then open up Edge and browse light websites. Chrome or Youtube will lag that thing. Meanwhile, they are being promoted as being perfectly capable to do stuff like light photoshopping, especially if they include some weird graphics card. I’ve seen laptops promoted for gaming because they have an i7 or i5, but without a dedicated graphics card. While you “can” play AAA (e-sport) titles on the latest i7 and i5 without a graphics card. It’ll play on 30FPS max. It’ll drop to unplayable FPS when anything happens in the game that is more taxing then just walking around. It won’t crash, but you won’t enjoy it.People have way to high expectations for laptops most of the time. Especially when they compare it to an smartphone or tablet. I mean, those devices are a lot smaller and can do it without lagging right? Well.. Yeah, but they are doing things a whole lot different. It’s like saying that you don’t need a car because you own a hoverboard/segway. Yes you can get around on that thing. But don’t expect to move your couch with it.

I had that general problem in September when I bought my current laptop. Basically, it was a software thing; Dropbox was included with the software suite on the laptop, and when I set it up for my account, the blasted thing insisted on downloading everything I currently have stored in my Dropbox account. I'm pretty sure someone will tell me that I could have adjusted my Dropbox settings to prevent that, in which case I respond "mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa". The point, though, is that (especially since my laptop doesn't have a SSD, just a HDD) downloading all my Dropbox files took a long time and a lot of CPU and HDD bandwidth while I was trying to set up various other things. It was pretty darn irritating.

Usually brand new laptops come with a lot of pre-installed software commonly refered to as “Bloatware” You can try removing those already, will likely make a big difference. On top of that, it obviously depends on the hardware specs of the machine, perhaps the laptop wasn’t that good in the first place. For a future purchase you’ll want to make sure you have “SSD” drives, rather than a traditional hard drive, it makes a MAJOR difference in the speed you experience of your computer. As for your specific case, it’s too hard to really give you an answer with the information provided.

Most new laptops come with a weird version of some antivirus software which is always a major issue on its own. Also there’s a lot of unwanted programs at startup which take time during boot as well as consuming resources in the background. Especially if it’s a Window system the default startup approach is to get everything running and it should be switched to a Selective startup with only the minimal needs.

That would depend on several factors: What processor and speed? How much RAM installed? How much free space on the system (C:) drive? What operating system is it running? Is the laptop plugged into power (it will usually run slower if not -- check your power settings). Are you doing more than one thing? Are there background processes running, like Dropbox sync'ing itself to the Internet? Is the program you are trying to run a resource hog (like Adobe Photoshop)? If you don't have enough RAM installed, and if you are running Windows, it may run out of physical memory and start swapping pages to disk, which will really slooooooooooooooooow things down. Check your performance monitor (CTRL+ALT+DEL, Task Manager, Options -> Performance) -- if you are running Windows. Not sure what else you can check.

Here are the known culprits : Bloatware ( unnecessary software that comes with the brand of your laptop)Windows updates ( when connected to wifi out of box)Antivirus ( mostly MCafee out of box free trial version)Cheap laptop ( Asus K541 laptop with onboard 2gb RAM and onboard CPU and other laptops of that design).Getting rid of 1,2,3 will improve your laptops perfomance.

There so many variable here. Without knowing the configuration of the laptop (OS, RAM, CPU) it would be hard to answer. If the slowness occurs during Internet browsing it could be your Internet Service and not your laptop. Another possibility is that some vendors load massive amounts of junk ware on new machines. Navigate to Add/Remove Program’s to see what is there. You can also launch the task manager to see what is consuming your memory and CPU during the slowness. Good luck.
